Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling is preparing for a stressful final exam and is feeling anxious about the outcome.
Situation2: The cleaner is checking the inventory of cleaning supplies during a routine clean.
Story: I was halfway through checking the cleaning supplies in the storage closet, clipboard in hand, when I heard my stepbrother’s door slam. He’d been holed up for days, cramming for his final exam, and I knew the pressure was getting to him. As the housekeeper, I was supposed to finish the inventory and report any shortages before the end of my shift. But as his step-sibling, I was expected to be there for him, to listen and offer comfort when he was anxious. I could hear him pacing, muttering formulas under his breath, and I felt the urge to drop everything and knock on his door, to remind him he wasn’t alone. But the list in my hand reminded me of the supplies I still had to count, the responsibilities I couldn’t ignore. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the brother who needed me, and the job that demanded my attention. I stood frozen in the hallway, torn between the roles I was supposed to fill, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
